titleStmt.title: A Petition to His Grace ye Duke of Grafton

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: It was my Lord ye Dextrous Shift,
Of t'other Ionathan, viz, Swift,
But now S,t Patricks Saucy Dean,
With Silver verg & Surplace clean,
Of oxford or of ormond's Grace
In Looser Rhimes to beg a place,
A Place he got yclep'd a Stall
And eke a thousand pounds withall;
& wehre he a less witty writer
He might as well, have got a MitreThus I the Ionathan of Cannor
In Humble Lays my thanks Do offer,
Approach your grace with gratefull Heart,
My thanks & verse, devoid of Art,
Content with what your Bounty Gave,
No Larger Income do I crave:
Rejocing yṭ in Better Times
Grafton requires my Loyal Lines
Proud while my Patriot is polite
I likewise do ye Patriot write.
Proud yṭ att once I can commend
King Georges & ye Muses friend.
Endeard to Brittain & to thee
Disjoin'd Hibernia by ye Sea,
Endear'd by twice 3 anxious Years
Employ'd In Guardian Toils, & cares;
By Love by Wisdom & by Skill,
For he hath Sav'd thee against thy will.But where shall Smedly make his nest
And lay his wand'ring head to rest?
Where shall he find a Decent house
To treat his friends & chear his Spouse?
Oh Lack, my Lord, Some pritty cure
In wholsom Air, & AEther Pure
The Gardon stor'd with artless flowers,
In Either Angle, shady Bowers
No Gay Parterre with Costly Green
Within ye Ambient Hedge be seen:
Let freely Nature take her course,
Nor fear from one ungratefull force,
Nor sheers shall check their sprouting vigour
Nor shape ye Yews to Antick figure:
A Limpid Brook will trouts Supply,
Round a Small Orchard may it run
Whose Apples redden to ye Sun.
Let all be snug & Warm & neat
For 50 twin'd a Safe retreat.
A little Euston may it be
Euston I'll carve on every tree.
And then To keep it in repair
My Lord──twice 50 pound a Year
Will Bravely Do──But if Your Grace
Wou'd make 'em Hundreds──charming Place
Thou then wou'dst shew another face.
Cl────n far north my Lord it Lyes,
Midst Snowy Hills, Inclement Skies,
One shivvers with ye Artick wind,
One Hears ye poplar Axis RingGring.
Good Iohn indeed, with beef & clarret,
Makes the place warm yṭ one may Bear it,
He has a purse to keep a Table,
And eke a Soul as Hospitable
My heart is good, but assets fail
To fight wtḥ Storms, & snow & Hail;
Besides ye country's big deletedthin of People,
Who seldom meet but in a steeple,
The strapping Dean ytṣ Gone to town
Ne'er Nam'd ye thing without a frown,
When Much fatigu'd wtḥ sermon Study
He felt his brains grow dull & Muddy
No fit companion, cou'd be found
To push ye Lazy Bottle round;
Sure then for want of Better folks
To pledge──his clark was orthodox.
Ah how unlike to Gerrard street,
Where Beaux & Belles in partys meet,
Where gilded chairs, & coaches Throng;
And Jostle as they Rowl along.
Where Tea & coffee hourly do flow
And Gape·seed does in Plenty grow;
And Griz──no clock more certain) crys
Exact at seven, hot mutton pies.
There Lady Luna, in her Sphere
out shone when Paunce·forth was not there
But now she wains, & as tis said
Keeps sober Hours, & goes to Bed.
There──But tis needless to write down
All ye Amusements of the Town;
And Spouse will think herself quite undone
To trudge blot to blot Cannor, from sweet London.
And care we much our wives to Please
Or else, we shou'd be Ill at Ease
You see my Lord what tis I Lack
Tis only some convenient tack,
Some Parsonage house wtḥ Garden Sweet
To be my Late, my last retreat;
A Decent church close by its Side,
There preaching, praying to reside;
And my time securely Rolls
To save my own & others Souls357-176Y
